channel.title: 经济学人
channel.description: 这是一个追踪经济学人news的种子

item.title: 众议院选举不像参议院选举那样对共和党不利。但民主党夺取众议院的可信度要高于共和党保住众议院的可信度👇。
item.description:
The House elections are not so tilted against the Republicans as the Senate elections are against the Democrats. But Democrats have a more credible case for taking the House than the Republicans do for keeping it https://t.co/avCi15xZU1 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: "他是个超级领袖他必须让人们相信他能在水上行走。"埃隆-马斯克表现得好像他肩负着拯救人类的使命。他的傲慢可能会有糟糕的结局👇。
item.description:
“He’s a mega leader. He has to make people believe he can walk on water.” Elon Musk acts as if he is on a mission to save humanity. His hubris may end badly https://t.co/e0duyKooGW 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 戴夫-卡尔霍恩（Dave Calhoun）即将卸任波音公司首席执行官一职。他的继任者尚未公布，将在这家航空巨头处于动荡时期时接过轭👇。
item.description:
Dave Calhoun is bowing out as chief executive of Boeing. His as-yet-unannounced successor will take the yoke in the middle of a turbulent time for the aerospace giant https://t.co/rWYZp2VeJS 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: "解决之道就是让 Etsy 变得更 Etsy"。@jgsilverman 在 "Money Talks "节目中告诉 @alice_fulwood 电子商务巨头如何应对 Temu 为赢得美国购物者的青睐而做出的努力🎧。
item.description:
“The solution is for Etsy to be even more Etsy.” @jgsilverman tells @alice_fulwood how the e-commerce giant is responding to Temu’s bid to win over American shoppers, on “Money Talks” https://t.co/g62szEccvi 🎧

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 在伊斯坦布尔即将举行的市长选举中，城市抗震政策一直是重要议题。在 "情报 "节目中@p_zalewski 解释了为什么这项任务在实践中会更加困难
item.description:
In Istanbul’s upcoming mayoral elections, policies to earthquake-proof the city have been high on the agenda. On “The Intelligence” @p_zalewski explains why the task will prove more difficult in practice https://t.co/HyXMPwYjeL pic.twitter.com/CkaSS4IP91

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 从纸面上看，欧洲应该能够为乌克兰提供足够的支持。问题是，好盟友所需的特质分布不均👇。
item.description:
On paper, Europe should be in a position to deliver more than enough support to Ukraine. The problem is that the attributes needed in a good ally are unevenly spread https://t.co/MrD17Xj5Sv 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 美国股市跑赢其他国家股市的时间越长，就越显得顺理成章。但有迹象表明，专业投资者已经无法忍受定价差异过大 👇 。
item.description:
The longer America’s stockmarket outperforms the rest, the more it seems like the natural way of things. But there are signs that the pricing differentials have grown too large for professional investors to tolerate https://t.co/PGEKRgGtQQ 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 化石的发现引发了一场圣经般的启示。"不可能的怪物》讲述了一个脍炙人口的故事，其精彩程度远超以往 👇。
item.description:
The discovery of fossils sparked a revelation of biblical proportions. “Impossible Monsters” tells a much-told tale better than it had been told before https://t.co/cFZm4XgIpg 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 今天的 "情报"：塞内加尔大选、伊斯坦布尔抗震以及肥狗背后的科学原理
item.description:
Today on “The Intelligence”: Senegal’s election, earthquake-proofing Istanbul and the science behind fat dogs https://t.co/yEl12Lq1mj

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 钱有可能太多吗？两本新书这样认为。但是，它们主张摒弃富人的论点简单、振奋人心，而且是错误的 💰
item.description:
Is it possible to have too much money? Two new books think so. But their arguments for doing away with the rich are simple, rousing and wrong https://t.co/ORaefrCll7 💰

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: "在所有摇摆州中，亚利桑那州拥有最多的拉美裔选民"。@daniella_raz在我们的 "制衡 "播客中解释了为什么亚利桑那州是研究美国拉美裔投票的好地方🎧。
item.description:
“Of all the swing states it has the largest share of Hispanic voters.” @daniella_raz explains why Arizona is a good place to study America’s Latino vote, on our “Checks and Balance” podcast https://t.co/wqWs5SFU9y 🎧

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: ♦️ 最高法院审理堕胎药案。♦️ 巴尔的摩的桥梁垮塌可能会产生长期影响。♦️ 唐纳德-特朗普的四项刑事审判之一的开庭日期已经确定。关注美国政治的最新动态： 👇
item.description:
♦️ The Supreme Court hears an abortion-pill case.

♦️ The bridge collapse in Baltimore may have long-term effects.

♦️ A start date is set for one of Donald Trump’s four criminal trials.

Follow the latest in American politics: https://t.co/fDr3bt6oCL 👇 pic.twitter.com/YlVCZ41X0h

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 在经历了抗议活动不断的竞选季后，塞内加尔选出了非洲最年轻的总统。在 "情报 "节目中@TomGardner18 解释了这位反建制的政治家是如何取得胜利的
item.description:
After a campaign season marred by protests, Senegal has elected Africa’s youngest president. On “The Intelligence” @TomGardner18 explains how the anti-establishment politician emerged victorious https://t.co/y2kdwRw5V4

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 一些观察家猜测，卢旺达总统可能会利用该国种族灭绝 30 周年纪念日来放松对其独裁国家的控制。保罗-卡加梅认为自己对这个仍然脆弱的国家来说是不可或缺的👇。
item.description:
Some observers speculate that Rwanda’s president may use the 30th anniversary of the country’s genocide to loosen the grip of his authoritarian state.

That is unlikely. Paul Kagame sees himself as indispensable to a still fragile place https://t.co/vxfeGdXd5r 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 在尼日利亚开采石油近七十年的壳牌石油公司已同意出售其陆上子公司。其他石油公司也在收拾行囊。这使人们对尼日利亚最重要的产业感到焦虑。
item.description:
Shell, which has been pumping oil in Nigeria for nearly seven decades, has agreed to sell its onshore subsidiary. Other oil firms are packing up too.

This is giving rise to anxiety over the country’s most vital industry https://t.co/Zu9mbobiTT 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 英国人对高速公路的热爱正在减退。但最近人们发现，M25 高速公路关闭时比开放时更令人恼火👇。
item.description:
Britain’s love affair with motorways is dimming. But recently people found the M25 even more irritating shut than open https://t.co/Ja2lj0EkTG 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 阿尔迪南美在大多数竞争对手都举步维艰的美国取得成功，部分原因是运气好。
item.description:
Aldi Süd has succeeded in America where most rivals have struggled partly thanks to luck.

But there is also another reason https://t.co/PUdpa4CnDi 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 玛莎百货拥有丰富的历史，而这些历史都包含在它自己的档案中。这里有过去衣橱中的幽灵：连身裤和开襟衫、套装和连体服、紧身裤和牛仔裤、睡衣和胸罩👇。
item.description:
Marks & Spencer has a rich history, and that history is contained in its own archive. There lie the ghosts of bygone wardrobes: jumpers and cardigans, suits and romper suits, leggings and jeggings, bed-jackets and bras https://t.co/y1ZJimyOHs 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 与狗共享一个家是人生最大的乐趣之一。但爱狗人士无权饲养像 XL Bully 这样最危险的犬种，从而危及他人的生命。还有更多品种可供选择 👇
item.description:
Sharing a home with a dog can be one of life’s greatest pleasures. But dog lovers have no right to endanger others’ lives by owning the most dangerous breeds like the XL Bully. There are plenty more to choose from https://t.co/J3u51ZlIpZ 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 研究发现，与没有横向调动的员工相比，开始横向调动的员工在职业生涯后期更有可能获得晋升，并享受更高的工资增长。先横向流动，才能向上发展🦀。
item.description:
Research has found that employees who embark on lateral moves are more likely to be promoted and to enjoy higher wage growth later in their careers than employees who did not.

You can move up by first moving sideways https://t.co/SSKKv3eXJk 🦀

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: "Freakonomics》（《怪诞经济学》）是这一波图书浪潮的顶点，它承诺对传统智慧所忽略的事物进行奇特而严谨的分析。这种方法很有趣，但已经失宠👇。
item.description:
“Freakonomics” was at the apex of a wave of books that promised a quirky—yet rigorous—analysis of things that the conventional wisdom had missed. The approach was fun, but has fallen out favour https://t.co/OhQj6nXyBG 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 不久前，咨询业看起来还坚不可摧。但自 19 大流行病以来，咨询业的增长一直萎靡不振，有三个问题使其复苏变得更加复杂 👇
item.description:
Not long ago the consulting industry looked indestructible. But growth has been soggy since the covid-19 pandemic, and three issues are complicating its recovery https://t.co/kFcyOEmOkF 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 许多人都认为穆萨卡（moussaka）--由味道浓郁的肉馅、沾满油的茄子和香浓的焦糖酱组成的邋遢方块--是希腊的国菜。它进入希腊美食的神殿，是传统如何形成的一课 👇。
item.description:
Many consider moussaka—sloppy squares of richly flavoured mince, oil-slicked aubergines and indulgent béchamel sauce—Greece’s national dish. Its entry into the pantheon of Greek gastronomy is a lesson in how traditions are forged https://t.co/HTXLBE0GvT 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 自罗伊案终审以来，美国最高法院将首次审理堕胎案件。一个问题可能会主导整个对话 👇
item.description:
For the first time since ending Roe, America’s Supreme Court will hear an abortion case. One question could dominate the conversation https://t.co/1uAYilk4qZ 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 如果穆罕默德-穆斯塔法（Mohammad Mustafa）真的开始解决巴勒斯坦人的无数问题，这位新任命的总理或许还能赢得一些支持。但合法性和振兴将来自投票箱，而他尚未确定选举日期👇。
item.description:
If Mohammad Mustafa actually begins fixing the Palestinians’ myriad problems, the newly appointed prime minister might yet win some support.

But legitimacy and revitalisation will come from the ballot box, and he is yet to set an election date https://t.co/IHPCOIOpdd 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 美国的购房者和卖房者在目前的方式下并没有为佣金支付合理的价格。而与一群中介达成的和解协议并不能保证他们将来会有这样的机会👇。
item.description:
Homebuyers and sellers in America do not pay a fair price for commissions under the current approach. And a settlement agreed with a group of agents offers no guarantee that they will have such a chance in the future https://t.co/PZILcE21ju 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: "有一种说法认为，曼德海峡（Bab al-Mandab）得名于那些在试图穿越海峡时被淹死的人所流下的眼泪。"海峡是一个咽喉还是一个渡口，取决于你是有货物需要守护，还是一无所有。摘自 1843 年杂志
item.description:
“One theory is that the Bab al-Mandab got its name from the tears shed for those who have drowned while trying to cross.”

Whether the strait is a chokepoint or a crossing depends whether you have goods to guard, or nothing to lose. From 1843 magazine https://t.co/kUMJulrJ03

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 摄入更少的卡路里可以防止衰老 👇
item.description:
Eating fewer calories can ward off ageing https://t.co/zJ5ohzhxVk 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 电动汽车正处于肥胖流行病的风口浪尖 👇
item.description:
EVs are in the middle of an obesity epidemic https://t.co/rEbVSTqWP8 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024

item.title: 发音、重音和节奏很少有人教得好 👇
item.description:
Pronunciation, stress and rhythm are rarely taught well https://t.co/gLodU0EIQP 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 26, 2024
